name: solanum-lycopersicum
definition: The tomato is the edible, often red, berry of the plant Solanum lycopersicum, commonly known as a tomato plant.
description:
Tomato is flowering plant of the nightshade family, cultivated extensively for its edible fruits.

There are 13 species of wild tomatoes in the world and over 3000 varieties created via selective breeding.

Labelled as a vegetable for nutritional purposes, tomatoes are a good source of vitamin C.

The plant can be erect with short stems or vine-like with long, spreading stems.

The stems are covered in coarse hairs and the leaves are arranged spirally.

The tomato plant produces yellow flowers, which can develop into a cyme of 3 to 12.

Its round fruit (berry) is fleshy, smoothed skinned and can be red, pink, purple, brown, orange or yellow in color.

The tomato plant can grow 0.7 to 2 meters in height and as an annual, is harvested after only one growing season.

Tomatoes are a significant source of umami flavor.

While tomatoes are fruits, they are commonly used as a vegetable ingredient or side dish.

The fruits are commonly eaten raw in salads, served as a cooked vegetable, used as an ingredient of various prepared dishes, and pickled.

Additionally, a large percentage of the world’s tomato crop is used for processing.

Products include canned tomatoes, tomato juice, ketchup, puree, paste, and sun-dried tomatoes or dehydrated pulp.

Numerous varieties of the tomato plant are widely grown in temperate climates across the world.

Greenhouses allow for the production of tomatoes throughout all seasons of the year.

Tomatoes are usually staked, tied, or caged to keep the stems and fruits off the ground.

Consistent watering is necessary to avoid blossom-end rot and cracking of the fruits.

The plants are susceptible to a number of pests and diseases, including bacterial wilt, early blight, mosaic virus, Fusarium wilt, nematodes, and tomato hornworms.

Many of these problems can be controlled with crop rotation, the use of fungicides and pesticides, and the planting of resistant varieties.

The species originated in western South America and Central America.

The Aztec word tomatl gave rise to the Spanish word tomate, from which the English word tomato derived.

Its domestication and use as a cultivated food may have originated with the indigenous peoples of Mexico.

The Aztecs used tomatoes in their cooking at the time of the Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire.

After the Spanish encountered the tomato for the first time after their contact with the Aztecs, they brought the plant to Europe.

From there, the tomato was introduced to other parts of the European-colonized world during the 16th century.

contextual.caption: Tomato plant requires relatively warm weather and much sunlight. It is grown chiefly in hothouses in cooler climates.

featured.caption:
Tomato plants typically grow between one to three meters in height.

The size of the tomato varies according to the cultivar, with a range of one to ten centimeters in width.

facts.name: Tomato grows like a vine
facts.value: Tomato grows like a vine. Stem is covered with fine hair which facilitates bonding to the ground or substrate.

facts.name: Tomato are actually fruits
facts.value: Although most people believe that tomato belongs to the group of vegetables, this plant actually belongs to the group of fruits. Fruit of tomato is called berry.

facts.name: Heaviest tomato had 3.51 kilograms
facts.value: Heaviest ever recorded tomato had 3.51 kilograms in weight. Longest ever recorded tomato had 48 centimeters in length.

facts.name: 150 million of tons of tomatoes per year
facts.value: Around 150 million of tons of tomatoes are produced annually. Greatest producer of tomato in the world is China.

facts.name: Leaves are up to 25 centimeters
facts.value: Leaves of tomato are usually 10 to 25 centimeters long and divided in 5 to 9 leaflets.

facts.name: Stem and leaves are poisoning
facts.value: Stem, leaves and green (unripe) fruit contain alkaloid called tomatine which can induce poisoning.

facts.name: Contains lycopene that is anti-cancerigene
facts.value: Tomato contains lycopene (chemical that belongs to the group of carotenoids) that can prevent development of certain types of cancer. Other than that, tomato has beneficial effect on the heart, blood pressure, cholesterol level and eye sight.

facts.name: Can remove smell released by skunk
facts.value: Tomato is rich in acids that can remove smell released by skunk. These acids can also be a part of various lotions and hygienic products that are used for cleansing of the body and various objects in the house.

facts.name: Scientific name is wolf peach
facts.value: Scientific name for tomato is Solanum lycopersicum. It means "wolf peach".

facts.name: Size of tomato depends on the species
facts.value: Size of tomato depends on the species. Smallest tomatoes have 1 to 2 centimeters, large tomatoes have 10 centimeters, while majority of cultivated tomatoes have 5 to 6 centimeters in diameter.

facts.name: Ripe tomato contains many vitamins
facts.value: Ripe tomato is safe and highly recommended piece of fruit because it contains high level of mineral and vitamins. Tomato can be consumed raw, in the form of soups, juices or as ketchup.

facts.name: Harvested unripe to prevent rotting
facts.value: Tomato is harvested unripe to prevent rotting and to ensure longer shelf-life. During the early '90, scientists created genetically modified tomato that can remain fresh extended period of time.

facts.name: Wild tomato is perennial plant
facts.value: Wild tomato is perennial plant (it lives more than two year). Cultivated tomato is annual plant (it lives one year).

facts.name: In the wild are pollinated by insects
facts.value: Tomatoes in the wild are pollinated by insects such as halictid bee. Cultured varieties of tomatoes can be self-pollinated. Some of them are pollinated by the help of artificial wind and by cultured bumblebees.

facts.name: Most popular tomato species are red
facts.value: Most popular tomato species are red. Cultivated tomatoes can also be yellow, orange, pink, green, black or white in color.
